content:
I just read some truly fascinating news from OpenAI about the introduction of "Apps in ChatGPT." ü§Ø This isn't just about integrating more tools; it feels like a fundamental shift in how we'll interact with AI.

The core idea is giving ChatGPT access to external applications, allowing it to perform actions like booking flights, ordering groceries, or even drafting documents through third-party services. This moves ChatGPT beyond a conversational AI into an *action-oriented* one.

What excites me most is the potential for unparalleled productivity. Imagine asking ChatGPT to "Find me a flight to London next month under $800 and add it to my calendar," and it simply *does* it. It abstracts away the need to open multiple apps and navigate different interfaces. It's truly a step closer to that seamless, intuitive personal assistant we've all dreamed about.

My personal take? This presents a massive opportunity for businesses to reimagine their customer experiences and internal workflows. Those who can seamlessly integrate their services with this new paradigm will likely gain a significant competitive edge. It also raises interesting questions about data privacy and security, which I'm sure OpenAI is carefully considering.

Are you as excited about the potential of "Apps in ChatGPT" as I am? How do you see this impacting your industry or daily tasks?

Wow, I just had an "aha!" moment that completely re-energized my week! ‚ú®

I‚Äôve been working with a fascinating new audio capture feature in the Lovable app, and honestly, I'm genuinely blown away by how seamlessly it's been imagined and implemented. 

It wasn't a complex set of instructions for the app ‚Äì just a few short prompts from me. But the transcription? It‚Äôs almost real-time. I can pause, restart, and it just‚Ä¶ works. Flawlessly.

It's moments like these, when technology exceeds your expectations and *just gets it*, that remind me of the power of intuitive design and thoughtful development. It's not just about building features; it's about anticipating needs and creating experiences that feel effortless.

What's a recent technology or tool that has genuinely surprised and delighted you with its execution? I'd love to hear about your "aha!" moments! üëá

Topic: Apple‚Äôs 3 biggest wins and 3 greatest failures of 2025

Summary: The tech industry has endured another turbulent year, buffeted by the continued rise of artificial intelligence and the economic threats posed by President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Even the most promi

Source: https://www.fastcompany.com/91448143/apple-3-biggest-wins-3-greatest-failures-2025-intelligence-iphone-17-liquid-glass-os

Here‚Äôs something I‚Äôve been mulling over after reading Fast Company's take on Apple's 2025 performance. It‚Äôs always fascinating to look at a tech giant like Apple and dissect their year. üßê

This year, AI's continued rise and the economic headwinds from President Trump's tariffs created a truly volatile landscape. Even for a company as robust as Apple, navigating this was a masterclass in strategy (and sometimes, a lesson in humility).

I found myself particularly intrigued by their successes in integrating AI more seamlessly into their ecosystem. It wasn't just about flashy new features; it was about truly enhancing user experience in subtle, yet powerful ways. That's a win that reverberates far beyond the quarterly earnings.

But where did they stumble? For me, it was less about a specific product failure and more about how certain ambitious projects perhaps overpromised and underdelivered on initial hype. In an era where consumer expectations are sky-high and patience is thin, managing that narrative is crucial.

It makes me wonder ‚Äì for all the innovation and progress we see, is the tech industry getting better at learning from its missteps, or are we destined to repeat some patterns year after year?

What are your thoughts on Apple's year, or generally, on how companies are faring in this rapidly evolving tech landscape? Share your perspective!

Ever had that sinking feeling when you've crafted the perfect LinkedIn post, only for it to disappear into the ether before you could hit publish? ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I certainly have.

It's a frustrating experience that many of us can relate to. We invest time and thought into our content, and losing it due to an accidental navigation or a sudden distraction is incredibly disheartening.

That's why I've been thinking a lot about the 'draft' functionality on platforms like LinkedIn. Imagine if, the moment you started writing a post, it was automatically saved as a draft. No more frantic copying and pasting just in case!

And what if there was a clearly visible "Save Draft" button that activated every time you made a change or even regenerated content? This would empower us to consciously save our progress, ensuring our efforts are never lost.

The best part? If you navigate away without explicitly saving, a gentle prompt would appear, asking if you‚Äôd like to save your work. It‚Äôs a small change, but it would make a monumental difference in our content creation workflow. It‚Äôs about building trust and respect for the content creators on the platform.

What are your thoughts on this? What small feature would dramatically improve your LinkedIn experience?
ai_prompt:
When I get to 'Edit Post' page, the produced draft should be Saved under Drafts by default for once. 

There should be 'Save Draft' button, which should be activated further if user makes further changes in the editor, or regenerates the post. 

When user clicks the 'Save Draft' button, the previously saved Draft should be updated with the latest updates. 

If the user does not click 'Save Draft', and navigates away from the screen, user should be prompted to save draft.

content:
When I get to 'Edit Post' page, the produced draft should be Saved under Drafts by default for once. 

There should be 'Save Draft' button, which should be activated further if user makes further changes in the editor, or regenerates the post. 

When user clicks the 'Save Draft' button, the previously saved Draft should be updated with the latest updates. 

If the user does not click 'Save Draft', and navigates away from the screen, user should be prompted to save draft.

Is your organization ready to navigate the uncharted waters of AI risk? While AI promises incredible innovation and efficiency, the conversation around managing its inherent risks is becoming more critical than ever. We're seeing a rapid acceleration in AI adoption, and with that comes a growing need for robust frameworks to ensure responsible and ethical implementation.

Think about it: from algorithmic bias in hiring to data privacy breaches in customer interactions, the potential pitfalls are real and can have significant reputational and financial consequences. It's not just about compliance; it's about building trust and ensuring the sustainable growth of your AI initiatives. Forward-thinking companies are proactively developing strategies to identify, assess, and mitigate these risks, turning potential liabilities into opportunities for greater transparency and accountability.

What are some of the biggest AI risks you're seeing emerge in your industry, and how are you preparing for them?
